prompt.p: A 35-year-old patient is being investigated for secondary hypertension and is found to have primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome).
What diagnostic key finding is likely on investigation?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Low renin levels) is Correct. Renin stimulates aldosterone production through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis but aldosterone production in Conn's is independent of this axis and levels would be suppressed through the effects of high aldosterone on salt and water retention.
Option B (Hyperglycaemia) is Incorrect. Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid without glucocorticoid action.
Option C (Hypokalaemia) is Incorrect. A characteristic finding in Conn's due to renal potassium loss.
Option D (Hyponatraemia) is Incorrect. Hypokalaemia is the characteristic finding.
Option E (Metabolic acidosis) is Incorrect. No change in acid–base balance is expected.
